Chapter 9, Part 2: Mindfulness. How does one abide contemplating phenomena in relation to internal phenomena?

Internal phenomena refer to one's own aggregates of perception and mental formations, which are already obtained and not lost in one's present continuum.

He further truly knows that the internal hindrance of sensual desire that has not yet arisen arises, that which has already arisen ceases, and that which has ceased does not arise again in the future.

What is the noble truth of suffering?

It refers to the suffering of birth, the suffering of old age, the suffering of sickness, the suffering of death, the suffering of being with what is disliked, the suffering of separation from what is loved, the suffering of not obtaining what is sought, and in brief, the suffering of the five appropriated aggregates.
What is the suffering of birth?
Birth refers to the various kinds of sentient beings.

In that case, the birth, arising, entering, appearing, obtaining aggregates, obtaining elements, obtaining sense bases, and the arising of the life faculty of the aggregates in the various groups of sentient beings is generally called birth.
For what causes and conditions is birth said to be suffering?

Because when sentient beings are born, they experience and accept various bodily sufferings, they experience and accept various mental sufferings, they experience and accept various bodily and mental sufferings, they experience and accept various bodily torments, they experience and accept various mental torments, they experience and accept various bodily and mental torments, they experience and accept various bodily burnings, they experience and accept various mental burnings, they experience and accept various bodily and mental burnings, birth is said to be suffering.
Furthermore, when being born, one experiences two kinds of suffering:
First, the suffering of suffering;
Second, the suffering of formations, therefore it is called the suffering of birth.
What is the suffering of old age?

Old age refers to the time of aging, when hair falls out and turns white, skin becomes loose and wrinkled, the body becomes bent and hunched, breathing becomes labored, one walks with a cane, the limbs become mottled and black, one withers and becomes dull, the faculties mature and decay, all conditioned things deteriorate, one becomes decrepit and weak - all of this is collectively called old age.
For what reason is old age said to be suffering?

When sentient beings are old, they experience and undergo various bodily sufferings, and so on, up to experiencing and undergoing various burnings of body and mind - for this reason, old age is said to be suffering.
Furthermore, when one is old, one experiences three kinds of suffering:
First, the suffering of suffering;
Second, the suffering of change;
Third, the suffering of the formative forces - for this reason, it is called the suffering of old age.
What is the suffering of sickness?

Illness refers to headaches, eye pain, ear pain, nose pain, tongue pain, face pain, lip pain, tooth pain, palate pain, throat pain, heart pain, wind illness, cough, shortness of breath, hiccups, leprosy, hemorrhoids, diarrhea, dysentery, chills, fever, insanity, epilepsy, vomiting, sores, swellings, ringworm, goiters, indigestion, diarrhea, and other various illnesses that arise based on the body and mind, all of which are collectively called illness.
For what reason is illness said to be suffering?

When sentient beings are ill, they experience and accept various bodily sufferings, and so on, up to experiencing and accepting various burnings of body and mind. For this reason, illness is said to be suffering.
Furthermore, when ill, one experiences two kinds of suffering:
First, the suffering of suffering;
Second, the suffering of change. For this reason, it is called the suffering of illness.
What is the suffering of death?

Death means that when the various kinds of sentient beings move, change, perish, retrogress, lose, separate, the consciousness ceases, the life faculty ceases to function, the aggregates are destroyed, and they die prematurely or are killed, this is generally called death.
For what reason is death said to be suffering?
Because when sentient beings die, they experience and accept various bodily sufferings, and so on up to experiencing and accepting various mental and physical torments, death is said to be suffering.
Furthermore, when dying, one experiences three kinds of suffering:
First, the suffering of suffering;
Second, the suffering of change;
Third, the suffering of the formative forces, therefore it is called the suffering of death.
What is the suffering of encountering what is disliked?

Encountering what is disliked means that sentient beings equally dislike, do not enjoy, are not pleased with, and are not satisfied with, but are together with, in one place, as companions, not separate, not different, not apart, not scattered, gathering and combining, this is generally called encountering what is disliked.
For what reason is it said that being with what is disliked is suffering?

When sentient beings are with what is disliked, they experience and accept various bodily sufferings, and so on, up to experiencing and accepting various burnings of body and mind. It is said that this is suffering.
Furthermore, when being with what is disliked, one experiences two kinds of suffering:
first, the suffering of suffering;
second, the suffering of formations. Therefore it is called the suffering of being with what is disliked.
What is the suffering of being separated from what is loved?

Being separated from what is loved means that those who are loved, delightful, pleasing, and agreeable are not together, do not share the same place, are not companions, are separated and scattered, do not gather, and do not unite. In general, this is called being separated from what is loved.
For what reason is it said that being separated from what is loved is suffering?

That is to say, when sentient beings are separated from what they love, they experience and accept various bodily sufferings, and so on, up to experiencing and accepting various burnings of body and mind. This is said to be suffering.
Furthermore, when separated from what is loved, one experiences three kinds of suffering:
first, the suffering of suffering;
second, the suffering of change;
third, the suffering of the formative forces. Therefore it is called the suffering of separation from what is loved.
What is the suffering of not obtaining what one longs for?

Not obtaining what one longs for refers to not obtaining, not meeting, not accomplishing, and not being in union with desirable forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and tactile objects, clothing, food and drink, bedding, and medicine that are necessary for sustaining the body. In general, this is called not obtaining what one longs for.
For what reasons is not obtaining what one longs for said to be suffering?

That is to say, when sentient beings do not obtain what they long for, they experience and accept various bodily sufferings, and so on, up to experiencing and accepting various burnings of body and mind. This is said to be suffering.
Furthermore, when seeking and not obtaining, one experiences two kinds of suffering:
First, the suffering of suffering;
Second, the suffering of change, therefore it is called the suffering of seeking and not obtaining.
What is meant by briefly explaining the suffering of the five aggregates of clinging in totality?

The five aggregates of clinging refer to the aggregate of form, the aggregate of feeling, the aggregate of perception, the aggregate of mental formations, and the aggregate of consciousness, collectively called the five aggregates of clinging.
For what reason is it briefly explained that the five aggregates of clinging in totality are suffering?
It is because the five aggregates of clinging are impermanent, changing, exhausting, and weak, and are subject to loss and destruction.
They are fleeting and do not last, decaying and impermanent, unreliable, and subject to change and decay.
They increase and decrease, temporarily abiding and quickly perishing, originally non-existent and then existent, and having existed, they return to non-existence.
For this reason, it is briefly explained that the five aggregates of clinging in totality are suffering.
As it is said, the aggregates of clinging are all by nature suffering, because they are not peaceful and violate the holy mind.

The various sufferings that are called the truth of suffering are called impermanent, truly impermanent, called suffering, truly suffering. Whether the Buddha appears in the world or not, the Dharma of suffering abides in the Dharma realm.

All Tathagatas naturally penetrate, equally realize, proclaim, establish, analyze, and reveal it, making it clear, saying: This is impermanent, this is suffering, this is the nature of impermanence, this is the nature of suffering, this is true, real, this is the truth, this is reality, not false, not empty, not inverted, not different, therefore it is called the truth of suffering.
As for the term noble truth, the noble ones refer to the Buddhas and the Buddha's disciples. This is their truth, meaning they know, see, understand, and realize it as the truth.
For this reason, it is called the noble truth of suffering.

Furthermore, the noble truth of suffering is a provisional designation, a conceptual imputation, a verbal expression called the noble truth of suffering, because the buddhas and their disciples, as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, have all established this name.
What is the noble truth of the arising of suffering?

It refers to all craving, craving for continued existence, craving accompanied by delight and attachment, delighting in this and that. This is briefly explained as the noble truth of the arising of suffering.

If explained in detail, there are two kinds of craving, three kinds of craving, and further three kinds of craving, four kinds of craving, five kinds of craving, six kinds of craving, as well as all unwholesome dharmas, all contaminated wholesome dharmas, all bonds, latent afflictions, secondary afflictions, entanglements, and so forth, which are all called the noble truth of the arising of suffering.
For what reasons are all craving, craving for continued existence, craving accompanied by delight and attachment, delighting in this and that, all called the noble truth of the arising of suffering?

That is to say, these four kinds of craving are all the fundamental roots, roads, and conditions for the arising of suffering in the past, future, and present. Expounded in detail up to this body's destruction in the future, suffering arises as a result caused by this. Therefore, it is said that this is called the noble truth of the accumulation of suffering.

For what causes and conditions are two kinds of craving, three kinds of craving, and also three kinds of craving, four kinds of craving, five kinds of craving, six kinds of craving, and all unwholesome dharmas, all wholesome dharmas with outflows, all bonds, latent tendencies, secondary afflictions, and entanglements, all called the noble truth of the accumulation of suffering?

That is to say, these dharmas are all the fundamental roots, roads, and conditions for the arising of suffering in the past, future, and present. Expounded in detail up to this body's destruction in the future, suffering arises as a result caused by this.
As it is said, craving and so forth are all the causes of suffering and can serve as fundamental roots, because they lead to various kinds of suffering.

As for the name noble truth, the noble ones refer to the Buddhas and the Buddha's disciples. This is their truth, meaning that they know, see, understand, and fully awaken to it as a truth.
For this reason, it is called the noble truth of the origin of suffering.

It is because if these four loves are not yet abandoned, not yet fully understood, not yet extinguished, not yet spit out, the fruits of future suffering will continue to arise;

Therefore, their complete abandonment, etc., is called the noble truth of the cessation of suffering.

Therefore, the complete elimination of these and so forth is called the noble truth of the cessation of suffering.
